position.marginalia_text: cuiusq[ue] Artis; statim discenda[e] ad serium vsum; reliqua[e] scholastica[e]
leuiter percurrenda[e], cum suaui contemptu. Ex Eudromi energetica disciplina. Nam vbiq[ue] vanitas vanitatu[m]: et stultoru[m] plena omnia.

marginalia.translation: The arts are worth nothing unless they are in some way pragmatic, being profitable for life through necessary deeds and profitable for the world through most useful actions. Whence these pragmatic actions themselves, of whatever art, must be learned immediatley for serious use; the remaining theories should be lightly skimmed through with pleasant disregard. The energetic discipline taken from Eudromus. For vanity is everywhere, and all things are full of fools.

position.marginalia_text: Qui excellentissimos Libros potest facere a[e]thereos,
miracula perpetrabit. Vis est enim a[e]therea, qua[e] sublimat, multiplicat, [ve]req[ue] magneticos montes exstruit immensi valoris.

marginalia.translation: He who can write most excellent divine books will perform miracles. Indeed power is divine when it elevates, multiplies, and erects magnetic rocks of boundless value.

position.marginalia_text: Seipsum quotidiè rectificare, sapientis est: nec ulla Epanorthosis tanti momenti. Hominem malo sublimatum, quàm omnes

marginalia.translation: He who straightens himself out daily is wise, and no correction is as important. I prefer an elevated man to all the Fifth Essences.

position.marginalia_text: Multum valet Ars: sed plurimum Natura; et Assuetudo, altera natura. Tanti interest, quod scitur intimè, exercere diligentissimè.

marginalia.translation: Art is worth much, but Nature is worth more, and habit is another form of nature. It is of great intrest that what is known profoundly be practiced most diligently.
